KÄÅ›yapa! There will be bhiká¹£us in the future who are like dogs chasing clods - here, facing non-Buddhists
The dog refers to the five kinds of objects such as form, the clod is like the objects, throwing is like fearing form, sound, smell, taste, and touch, demonstrating fear of all objects.
Fearing those objects, not realizing and knowing the cause of fear, demonstrating having four kinds of characteristics, therefore only chasing objects.
Dwelling in a secluded place means wanting to attain superior objects, taking a secluded place.
Dwelling alone without companions, eliminating that defilement, permanently dwelling in non-duality, with the body apart from the five desires but the mind not abandoning them.
This person sometimes may recall good sounds, smells, tastes, and touches, the greedy mind slightly attached without contemplating internally, not knowing and not being aware of them.
Remembering various objects, enduring them, therefore they do not know.
How can one attain separation from form, sound, smell, taste, and touch?

Because they do not know and do not realize, later they come to enter cities, villages, kingdoms, and so forth among the people, and are again bound by the five desires of good form, sound, smell, taste, and touch, and thus they fall back again.
If they die in a secluded place, because they uphold worldly precepts, they will be reborn in the heavens, bound by the love of the five desires of the upper heavens.
Again, from the heavens they will perish, and will not be free from the four evil paths.
What are the four?
Namely, the paths of hell, hungry ghosts, animals, and asuras.
Rebirth in the heavens ends by relying on the practice of craving, so the black faction should be known. It is said that the white faction should be known by relying on the practice of views.
Because of seeing the non-self of the person, their antidotes are explained to accomplish the two kinds of black and white factions, and so forth, which should be known.
Thus, having cultivated various practices, there are scattered minds that cause them to be taken in, and those that are taken in are caused to attain liberation.

Among them, the sutra phrases and metaphors are used to explain the methods of shamatha for attaining liberation through an undirected mind, and to correct the confused mind that grasps and abandons the characteristics of shamatha and afflictions, etc., thus the metaphors of the throat and the bound person are explicitly explained.

In the one-pointed concentrated mind, the methods of liberation are explained, demonstrating the characteristics of seeing and cultivation, and the methods for eliminating afflictions are explained, because they obstruct the view of the body and the enjoyment of samadhi, like the throat and the bound person.
When realizing the truth, it is made difficult by means of supramundane wisdom, and the view of the body should be known as a disease in the throat.
Having practiced in this way, in order to prevent the dharmas of existence and so forth, two kinds of emptiness metaphors are explained for the impure mind:
First, reading and reciting the scriptures and treatises of worldly non-Buddhists, etc.;
Second, accumulating many good robes and bowls based on karma and the body.
These two dharmas can cause two kinds of bonds, in order:
First, the bond of views;
The second is the fetter of material gain, fame, and so forth.
However, these two kinds of fetters prevent the arising of wholesome dharmas that have not yet arisen, and cause the attainment of two kinds of dharmas:
First, the group of the noble lineage;
Second, being close to various benefactors.
Because they can destroy and defile wholesome dharmas that have already arisen, they cause the attainment of two kinds of defilements:
First, enduring various afflictions;
Second, being greedy for various benefactors, acquaintances, and so forth.
Because they permanently sever and uproot wholesome dharmas, they cause the attainment of two kinds of rain and hail that destroy the Dharma:
First, slandering the true Dharma;
Second, breaking the precepts and receiving the offerings of faith from others.
Because they are incurable in the present life, they cause the attainment of two kinds of boils and sores:
First, seeking to see the faults of others;
Second, covering up one's own offenses.
Because of evil conduct that is painful in the present life, they cause the attainment of two kinds of burning dharmas:
First, with a defiled body and mind, one receives and clings to the kasaya robe;
Second, accepting the worship, offerings, etc. of others who uphold precepts and possess merit.
The future analogy is because of being unable to give rise to attainment or non-attainment, causing the incurable illness of the two kinds:
First, harboring the conceit of superiority and subduing one's own mind;
Second, destroying others' resolve to give rise to the MahÄyÄna mind.
Because of slandering bodhisattvas, relying on the precepts of Å›rÄvakas, there will be further gradual [stages] in the future, which should be known.
KÄÅ›yapa!

One should observe oneself internally - in this way, up to who among them is wise? - in order to subdue greed, vexation, etc., the analogy of the superior precepts practice and extensive learning is spoken.
In order to give rise to a sense of disgust and regret, the superior mind precepts practice is clarified.
The analogy of the throat and the analogy of a bound person are because of the non-self of persons and the non-self of dharmas, the superior wisdom precepts practice.
If it is the superior mind precepts practice spoken of in the sÅ«tras for subduing greed, vexation, etc., why is the superior precepts practice spoken of here?
The answer is:
Because it can give rise to greed and affliction.
Sins are often caused by the arising of greed, hatred, delusion, and so forth. Therefore, it is said that subduing greed, affliction, and so forth is the supreme practice of precepts.
Question:
How do greed, affliction, and so forth give rise to sin?
Answer:
Because there are two kinds of characteristics.
Like those who are unable to repent;
Like those who repent but do not achieve repentance.
It is like if there are Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as who do not know the causes of afflictions, and are afraid of forms and other sense objects.
Dwelling in a secluded and empty place, they give rise to unwholesome thoughts in their own minds, and thus also give rise to greed, affliction, and the sense objects of self-conceit.
Or thinking of them elsewhere, seeing greed and so forth following like a dog chasing after a clod of dirt, chasing after the clod because of being hit by the clod.
In this way, because greed and so forth are not eliminated, if one makes present thoughts of things to be closely associated with such as villages and so forth, this is called not yet eliminated.
Because it accords with the meaning, it is called eliminated and completely eliminated.
Why does the black group speak of subduing greed but not of subduing vexation, while the white group speaks of subduing vexation but not of subduing greed?
The answer is:
Because both are in the desire realm, it shows that some are subdued and some are not subdued.

Showing that some are subdued and some are not subdued means that if one dies in a secluded place, then because it is not subdued, even one who abides in precepts will be destroyed, because one has accomplished superior precepts;
how much more so for one who does not abide in precepts, like a horse going off course or making mistakes.
In this way, a practitioner practices superior precepts, but because of mistakes and forgetfulness, it is also called confusion, like a throat ailment that can cut off the life root.

In this way, relying on the superior wisdom of practicing non-self in persons, one can cut off the life root of the Dharma through the view of a self, like a person seeking liberation from wherever they are bound.
In this way, relying on the superior wisdom of practicing non-self in dharmas, one follows the nature and liberation, and causes false thoughts to reckon with the mind.

Among these three cultivations of precepts, there are eight kinds of precepts that are contrary to the Dharma, and there are eight kinds of defilements that follow the mind, such as reading and reciting worldly non-Buddhist scriptures and treatises, and having too many good robes and alms bowls, etc., because they are of no use.
Just as emptiness is horizontally defiled, horizontal defilement is the cause of bondage, so the two kinds of bondage are gradually explained:
The first is the bondage of views;
The second is the bondage of fame, profit, and offerings.
Because it causes bondage, this gradual explanation is given.ğŸ”½Because of the bondage of views, one hates and slanders the holy ones and their friends.
Because of fame, profit, and offerings, one associates with laypeople.
Because defilements are like the cause of obstacles, the two kinds of defilements are gradually explained:
The first is hating and slandering the holy ones and their friends, and enduring various afflictions;
The second is associating with laypeople, and being greedy for various patrons and acquaintances, etc.
These defilements are like the cause of hail, so the hail is subsequently explained.
Because of enduring various afflictions, one slanders the true Dharma.
Because of greed for various donors, due to the condition of intimacy with the precept-breaking, it is said that the precept-breaker receives people's faith and offerings.

Because of the cause of hail, next there is a boil, because of slandering the true Dharma and receiving people's faith and offerings while breaking precepts, and because of covering up one's own offenses.

Because of the cause of burning and cooking boils, next the method of burning is explained. Seeking to see others' faults, speaking with a defiled mind and body, receiving and clinging to the kasaya robe, because of covering up one's own offenses, receiving the worship, offerings, etc. of others who uphold the precepts and have merit.

Because of the cause of burning and forming illness, next the incurable illness is explained, therefore it is said that with a defiled mind and body, one receives and clings to the kasaya robe, harbors arrogance, and accumulates the mind of precepts, therefore receiving the worship, offerings, etc. made by others who uphold the precepts and have merit, destroying others' minds set on the Great Vehicle.
In response to this, the white faction should be known.
Among these two people, the first is a person of seeing practice, and the second is a person of greed and love practice, this should be known.
How are the four kinds of Å›ramaá¹‡as gradually revealed?
As for the faults of violating precepts, either associating with them or abandoning them, one may obtain human faults or human merits, and all that which becomes an obstacle in mindfulness.
Or that which is not an obstacle, that is revealed as the three kinds of human faults, based on the three kinds of people, it should be known.
The Å›ramaá¹‡a of appearance and attire has both mind and practice destroyed, based on the delight in evil, it is said based on meaning.
The deceitful Å›ramaá¹‡a and the famous Å›ramaá¹‡a have accomplished practice but have a destroyed mind, based on the two kinds of great delight and desire and the delight in existence.
Among them, the delight in evil means if one says one is a Å›ramaá¹‡a but is not a Å›ramaá¹‡a.
The fear of the great means if one has various merits, but one's mind is in excess, one always thinks like this.
The delight in existence means if one has merits but gives rise to a mind equal to those with merits.
The first has two kinds of destroyed practices:
one, with remainder;
two, without remainder.
With remainder means:
It should be known that it is based on the four Å›ramaá¹‡as.
Based on accepting precepts, up to practicing impure mental actions;
Based on these three, the lack of skillful taming, etc. are shown in sequence.
Based on begging for food, it is said to be an impure livelihood.
Based on enjoyment, it is said that stingy enjoyment, hoarding, storing, and sleeping, etc. are not pure.
Based on cultivating practices, it is said to be an impure livelihood.
Based on enjoyment, it is said that stingy enjoyment, hoarding, storing, and sleeping, etc. are not pure.
Based on cultivating practices, it is said to be laziness.
Without remainder means that because of breaking precepts, one teaches to violate the fundamental precepts.
Ruining the mind means because of evil dharmas, and because of concealing them.
The second is based on accomplishment, practice, livelihood, precepts, enjoyment, and cultivation of the path.
Among them, accomplishment of practice is based on practice.
Accomplishment of objects is based on livelihood.
Accomplishment of deportment is based on the four practices with defiled mind.
Relying on precepts means using coarse and rough food, thus being content with few desires.
The four noble lineages means relying on enjoyment, not associating with monks and laypeople, and relying on cultivating the path.
Speaking little and having few words means delighting in tranquility.
Relying on discussing and comforting, etc., should be known.
Although practicing such dharmas, all are deceitful and not for the sake of pure mind, because the mind is spoiled.
Relying on practicing practice, deceitfulness should be known.
Always having the view of self means relying on the non-self of persons, not extinguishing the view of self and practicing.
In empty dharmas, fear and difficulty arise, like facing a deep pit.
Relying on the non-self of dharmas, not discriminating emptiness, and giving rise to the notion of an enemy towards its expounders.
Third means accomplishing practice, following, abiding, mindfulness, reliance, and practice, in accordance with all dharmas, should be known.
Among them, abiding means upholding precepts, mindfulness means much learning, and because of being mindful of them, one attains following all matters.
Relying means sitting in a secluded place, because sitting in a secluded place accords with all merits.
Following all dharmas means having few desires and being content with little, etc.
Opposing the mind towards relatives should be understood.
Not extinguishing all thoughts here shows having disgust and desire.
Because of that, extinguishing burning, etc., is for the sake of desiring enlightenment.
Extinguishing enlightenment is because of the practice of the path and its fruits.
The fourth person accomplishes both, and should be known through the power of the nine kinds of accomplishment.
First, the power of constant practice;
second, the power of much learning;
third, the power of desire;
fourth, the power of tranquil contemplation;
fifth, the power of right view;
sixth, the power of realization;
seventh, the power of extinction;
eighth, the power of cultivation;
ninth, the power of correct realization.
Not seeking body and life means not cherishing body and life, and this should be known as the power of constant practice.
The mind delights in hearing the Dharma of emptiness, etc., clarifies the second power of much learning.
Also, not delighting in the view of emptiness, etc., and not delighting in nirvana and cultivating the brahma-conduct, let alone aspiring for the three realms.
Not aspiring for the various views and dharmas, one should also extinguish the dharmas.
Because of the mind that attains nirvana through its fruition and path, the third power of aspiration is explained.
Always relying on the Dharma, not relying on the written words and phrases, the various afflictions seek inner liberation, not running away externally.
Because of relying on the Dharma, one seeks the wisdom of the mind and world of the meditation liberations.

The fourth power of tranquil contemplation, always seeking liberation from all afflictions without seeking externally, seeing that one dharma is originally free from defilements and ultimately pure, and relying on oneself without relying on others, is because of the nature of non-attachment.
There are worldly dharmas beyond learning that one knows and sees within oneself.
The fifth is the power of right view. Even the Dharma body is not seen, let alone the form body. Because the Three Jewels are not seen,
the true Three Jewels are also distinguished and remembered by supramundane wisdom.
The sixth is the power of realization. Since emptiness and suffering are not seen above, let alone being attached to sounds and words, because what should be eliminated is eliminated.
The seventh is the power of extinction. There is nothing to cultivate that should be cultivated, because it is cultivated.

The eighth is the power of cultivation. Not giving rise to birth and death, not attached to nirvana, knowing that all dharmas are originally quiescent and extinguished, not seeing bondage, not seeking liberation.
Therefore, not abandoning the world, not realizing nirvana, because the causes of the world are extinguished,
and because nirvana is attained, not giving rise to the world, not seeking nirvana, not hoping for death or life, not seeking liberation or bondage, because it is already extinguished,
and because there are remaining parts, it does not function and is not extinguished.
The unlearned dharmas included in the knowledge of the extinction of nature, the knowledge of non-arising, and so forth should be known as the ninth correct realization.

The three kinds of Å›ramaá¹‡as who establish the name of Å›ramaá¹‡a are said to have no meaning in that name and to be shown as dissimilar, because they are cut down by the name. Therefore, the parable of poverty is told.
How are they cut down by the name?

Because they have the form and appearance of a Å›ramaá¹‡a but not the name, they falsely receive the offerings of faith and support. From this point on, they are not true practitioners of the Å›ramaá¹‡a, and because they recognize and know the true practitioners of the Å›ramaá¹‡a and give rise to pride, and because they hold precepts that are upside down and resemble the precepts that are held.
The knowledge of hearing, thinking, and cultivation and so forth are cut down by pride. Therefore, two parables are told.
It is like a person who is swept away by a great flood and dies of thirst and exhaustion.
This parable shows that because of having the wisdom of hearing, pride arises.
The parable of the medicine master shows that because of having the wisdom of thinking, one delights in the samÄdhi of liberation.
Ordinary beings who are free from desire are attached to offerings and respect.
Those in training who give rise to regret and cultivate samÄdhi are practicing wisdom wrongly.
In order to show that they give rise to conceit in the midst of practicing correctly, the remaining three similes are told.
The first is the simile of the sick person;
the second is the jewel simile;
the third is the dead person simile. Relying on the precepts to give rise to conceit, four kinds of precept-breaking bhiká¹£us are shown.
The similes of oneself well upholding the precepts, etc., are as follows: The first is falsely receiving the precepts;
the second is explaining the lack of skill in upholding the vinaya and being lazy;
the third is because of practicing like them, in order to destroy the obstacles of precept-breaking, it is said to destroy the obstacles of the precepts;
the fourth explains fully receiving the twelve dhÅ«tas, which is nominally upholding the precepts.
Among them, the first is seen to destroy the obstacles of precept-breaking, and is therefore called precept-breaking, which should be known.
The first is because of breaking precepts, one cannot uphold them, and gives rise to fear in nirvana, unable to eliminate the obstacles of breaking precepts, thus practicing the antidotes.
The second is because of self-conceit, one gives rise to the appearance of attaining liberation, in order to counteract that, it is said that the merits of upholding precepts are true.

However, breaking precepts is manifested by evil, and cultivation is manifested by practice. Among them, the first upholder of precepts says that the internal sense bases are not the external sense bases.

The second says that defiled actions are non-actions, and wholesome non-actions are not created by the body, etc. Defiled actions are also non-actions, and are able to create wholesome non-activities, based on defilement and non-defilement, based on begging for food, without activity or non-activity, based on the enjoyment of defilement and non-defilement, there is no name, no form, no other nirvana, no thought, no non-thought, in the midst of formless activities, one is free from thoughts of everything, thus.

And thinking of the precepts without conceptualization, without extinction, and without non-extinction, because the practice of no-more-learning remains in nirvana with remainder and without afflictions.
Without grasping and without abandoning, always practicing the abandonment of joy and sorrow, and because equanimity and mindfulness are born together.
There is nothing to grasp and nothing to abandon, returning to that original realm, not grasping joy and sorrow, and because grasping equanimity and mindfulness are born together.
No sentient beings and no name of sentient beings, up to no mind.
No name of mind, relying on the explanation of the analogy.

Having already extinguished, according to what can be recorded and according to what is recorded, according to what is, no world and no non-world, relying on the mixed and unmixed activities of the person in the vessel world.
Speaking of no reliance and no non-reliance, relying on the defiled and undefiled, relying on the six consciousnesses, villages, fields, and objects.
Speaking of not being arrogant due to precepts and not slandering the precepts of others, relying on the family of intimacy.
They also do not remember and discriminate that precept, and do not discriminate that I am upholding the precepts, I have such upholding of the precepts, because they do not discriminate that nature.
The uncontaminated also have worldly common destructions, because they are immediately manifested, it is said to be uncommon.
However, if they are not the fruits of the three realms, and not seeking the causes of the three realms, these two phrases show this, which is called gradual.

Based on the precepts, there are various dharmas that accord with and go against them, therefore it is said that the distinctions of the affairs of good and bad students of the renunciant life are taught.
What is a bad student of the renunciant life?
Herein there are three kinds that should be known.
The renunciant who is similar in appearance and attire.

They do not cherish the precepts of the renunciant, only the appearance and attire are the same. Those who are not the same have different life, enjoyment, and views from the life, precepts, and mind of the renunciant.
Herein, because of the place of appearance and the place of attire, it is called similar in appearance and attire.
Herein, the place of attire is called the same attire because of their saá¹ƒghÄá¹­Ä« and so forth.

As for form and appearance, it is called having the same form because of shaving the beard and hair and holding a begging bowl.ğŸ”½Because of impure bodily actions and so forth, it is called having dissimilar conduct.
Because of an impure livelihood, it is called having a dissimilar livelihood.
Because of stinginess, it is called dissimilar in enjoyment.ğŸ”½Because of laziness, it is called dissimilar in practice.
Because of breaking the precepts, it is called dissimilar in upholding the precepts.
Because of evil dharmas, it is called dissimilar in views.
Because of being undisciplined, unrestrained, and not concealing the faculties, it is called dissimilar in mind.
The second, the deceitful and hypocritical bhiká¹£u, should be understood in terms of begging for resources, diligently practicing, and so forth.
The superior concentration and superior wisdom are the same as their practice and mind, but dissimilar in terms of accomplishing the intended meaning and so forth.
The superior precepts are the same as being single-minded and composed, up to not delighting in confusion.
The practice of superior concentration is the same as speaking and acting little.
The superior wisdom practice is the same, but the mind of deception and other practices is not the same.
The third, the famous Å›ramaá¹‡a, only seeks fame, you should know.

The samatha portion is the same, the vipaÅ›yanÄ portion is the same, the cultivation of those two portions is the same, and the auxiliary practices for those two are the same, but the mind-nature is not the same.
Among them, because of precepts, due to the portion of precepts, the samatha portion is the same, because precepts are the cause of samÄdhi.
Because of much learning, the vipaÅ›yanÄ portion is the same, because learning can grasp the uncontaminated wisdom.
Because of dwelling in emptiness and seclusion, the cultivation of those two is similar, because dwelling in an empty place and practicing are the causes of cultivation.
Few desires and so forth are the same as the auxiliary path of those two, because few desires and so forth are the auxiliary practices of cultivation and so forth.
Because of being close to others, the mind is not similar, you should know.
What is the well-trained Å›ramaá¹‡a?
There are four aspects that should be known:
Because of practice, mind, realization, and ultimate attainment.
Because of not cherishing one's body and life, in the present Dharma one attains the practice of disgust and remorse.
Because of delighting in the mind of emptiness and so forth, in future lives one teaches and transforms the body and practice.
This is called the power of practice, which should be known.

Because of practicing according to true suchness, because of believing in the non-self of dharmas, because of not delighting in nirvÄá¹‡a, and because of not delighting in emptiness, what should be attained and what is able to be attained, those are also free from the characteristics of falsely imagined nature and incorrect grasping.
Always rely on the definitive meaning and do not rely on the words and letters means seeking the necessary meaning.
Within afflictions, seek liberation, do not flee externally, and do not follow the nature of sounds.
This is called the power of mind, which should be known.

Seeing that the essence of all dharmas is eternally pure and unstained, because of the Dharma of true suchness, creating what assists one's own form and others, not relying on the nature of other's wisdom, and realizing without being stained.
In this, all retributions and so forth are seen as liberation, because the characteristics of nominal nature are not seen.
This is called the power of realization.
Because all sentient beings are inherently extinguished, they do not practice well and cultivate the antidotes to all afflictions and defilements.
They do not attain nirvana, because true suchness is uninterrupted, and because they do not observe non-events.
This is called the power of reaching the end.
Among them, the analogy of the poor man and the Å›ramaá¹‡a who does not learn well are to be understood in terms of three aspects, as the meaning does not correspond to the name.
One whose mind is ruined but whose practice is accomplished, one whose mind is accomplished but whose practice is ruined, and one whose mind is ruined and whose practice is also ruined.
Among them, there are three kinds of those whose minds are ruined but whose practice is accomplished that should be known.
The mind that is content with what is heard and what is to be heard, being content with what is taught in them, attaining worldly samÄdhi, and taking delight in attaining those merits.
Among them, the river of drifting and falling metaphor explains the destruction of the mind and the accomplishment of practice, only the matters of hearing and so forth should be known.
The doctor metaphor, still only the matters of explanation should be known.
The illusion metaphor, attaining the worldly samÄdhi, only delighting in those matters should be known.
The maá¹‡i jewel metaphor, accomplishing the mind but destroying the practice should be known.
The death metaphor, explaining the destruction of the mind and the destruction of practice should be known.
The elder's son metaphor, accomplishing the mind and accomplishing the practice should be known.
Because of the meaning of one characteristic, the well-trained Å›ramaá¹‡a should be known.
It is said that there are four kinds of bhiká¹£us who violate the precepts but appear to uphold them well. What is the sequence?
With the true Å›ramaá¹‡a, showing the acceptance of true practice.
Showing the semblance of abiding in precepts, showing the nominal precepts.
What is the nominal precepts?
There are four kinds of practices of abiding in nominal precepts that should be known.
Because they are destroyed by arrogance and so on, they are called abiding in the practice of precepts based on mere names.
The first one accomplishes the six kinds of precepts and is destroyed by the two kinds of obstacles.
What are the six kinds of precepts that are accomplished?
Relying on the precepts as explained, one accomplishes practice, accomplishes the destruction of the realm of practice, sees fear in even the slightest offense, and receives and practices.
There are two kinds of obstacles to the precepts.
What are the two kinds?
The flourishing of the view of the body causes the arising of precepts and the knowledge of life.
The second abandons those two afflictions and is free from the place of the flourishing of the view of the body.
Because of being a vinaya master, one is able to give rise to all offenses.
However, because of being equal to worldly purity, one is not moved by all benefits and gains, and is born together with the view of the body.

The third, having attained worldly pure precepts together with this same dharma, is born together with the view of the body, does not understand the non-self of dharmas, and hears the arising of fear and laziness.
Fourth, leaving all with suffering, but due to believing in wrong teachings and having no self, one destroys the pride of precepts and abides in the four kinds of improper precepts.
The precepts of knowing and recognizing slander and so forth, their characteristics and their undefiled nature should be known.
What are the dharmas of slander and so forth?
The first abiding in the precepts of nominal designation, also seeing self, also saying there is self, in order to counteract that, saying there is no self and no self of others.
The one who commits offenses in what is done is called non-action, in order to counteract that, saying there is no action and no non-action.

The one who performs actions is also not a performer, in order to counteract that, saying there is no agent and no non-agent.ğŸ”½The one who practices with ease is also called a non-practitioner, in order to counteract that, saying there is no practice and no non-practice.
The one who practices with false thoughts is called a non-practitioner, in order to counteract that, saying there is no practice and no non-practice.

The second is the practice of precepts based on false names, which accords with the afflictions of the faction of the view of self, and also sees names and forms. To counteract that, it says no names, no forms.
The future birth, the existence of the attainment of concentration on the idea of non-existence, and the idea of that, to counteract that, it says no idea of non-existence.
The one who extinguishes the burning afflictions is also called non-extinguishment. To counteract that, it says no extinguishment, no non-extinguishment.
Grasping the non-self of persons and abandoning the grasping of persons, to counteract that, it says no grasping, no abandoning.
Within the grasping of the non-self of sentient beings, it is also possible to grasp and also impossible to grasp. To counteract that, it says no possible grasping, no possible abandoning.
Not grasping the characteristics of sentient beings with form, etc., that is said to be good grasping. To counteract that, it says no sentient beings, no name of sentient beings.
Speech also speaks of that good grasping discrimination. To counteract that, it says no body, no name of body, no mouth, no name of mouth.
The discrimination of that mind and the discrimination of taking that as excellent are opposed to that, so it is said there is no mind and no discrimination of mind.

The third, the practitioner abiding in precepts, is not of the world because they are born in the world and also turn away from the lower, and to counteract that, it is said there is no world and no non-world.
Relying on samÄdhi and also relying on non-greed, to counteract that, it is said there is no reliance and no non-reliance.
